docs.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH more and more community hospitals are joining large networks like the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System and the Long Island Health Network, they insist they are not sacrificing their community roots. But some of the doctors who work for competing local hospitals say that's not the case. One administrator who takes the positive view is J. Ronald Gaud reault, the president and chief executive of Huntington Hospital. ''The core of what we do is still what you would normally think of as a community hospital -- providing for most of the health-care needs of the people in our service area,'' he said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Only a year ago, Peruvians went to the polls to choose a president in an election so clumsily fraudulent that it eventually forced the winner, the two-time incumbent, Alberto K. Fujimori, to desert the country and resign from exile in Tokyo. On Sunday, Peruvians will vote again for president after a campaign that has bordered on a political circus, complete with daily dancing and singing of candidates, ancient Inca symbolism and the tossing about of racist slurs, charges of drug use and marital misdeeds.

headline.main: In a Colorful Campaign in Peru, 3 Points of View Emerge

docs.abstract: Peruvians to vote for new president just year after election so clumsily fraudulent that winner, Alberto Fujimori, finally had to leave country and resign; Alejandro Toledo is likely to get most votes but not enough to avoid runoff, so that real race is between left-wing former president Alan Garcia and moderate conservative Lourdes Flores; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Only a year ago, Peruvians went to the polls to choose a president in an election so clumsily fraudulent that it eventually forced the winner, the two-time incumbent, Alberto K. Fujimori, to desert the country and resign from exile in Tokyo.    On...

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1997, Steve Ducharme was carrying plasterboard when he heard something pop in his arm and felt something strange in his armpit. It was his biceps muscle, which had snapped and then sprung back into his armpit like a recoiling window shade. That started the worst of bad times for Mr. Ducharme, a carpenter in this southern Maine town: unemployment, bankruptcy, a repossessed car, the works.

headline.main: Working Hard, Doing Well, Less Than Excited About Bush's Tax Plan

docs.abstract: Final article in series Judging the Tax Cut reports on Steve and Lisa Ducharme, Maine couple with three children who have just moved into home they were able to buy because of boost during economic boom; photo; working-class couple's new prosperity dims their enthusiasm for Pres Bush's tax cut, since what they most fear is recession; they also say they would rather see money go to the truly needy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate took a small step toward reducing the number of people without health insurance this week when it called for spending an additional $28 billion over three years to cover adults with incomes too high to qualify for Medicaid. The Oregon senators, Ron Wyden and Gordon H. Smith, Democrat and Republican respectively, proposed the change in the budget resolution, and it was adopted without dissent. But without the detailed legislation that the resolution called on the Finance Committee to develop, there was no clear sense of how many people would be covered.

headline.main: Senate Takes Small Step Toward Health Coverage for Uninsured

docs.abstract: Senate votes to spend additional $28 billion over three years to cover health insurance for adults with incomes too high for Medicaid; precise formula will be determined in conference (S)
docs.snippet: The Senate took a small step toward reducing the number of people without health insurance this week when it called for spending an additional $28 billion over three years to cover adults with incomes too high to qualify for Medicaid.    The Oregon...

docs.lead_paragraph: TWELVE years ago, Felycia Martin's purse was stolen from the hospital while she was giving birth to her son. A year ago, she started receiving dozens of bills for charges she did not recognize. There was a $3,000 cell phone bill and a $1,800 bill from Blockbuster Video. Then there was an $18,000 loan that had been taken out in her name at Wells Fargo, in addition to a $2,500 student loan from another bank. And most recently, she found that someone has been receiving welfare benefits in California under her name for the last two years.

headline.main: Personal Business; Fighting Back When Someone Steals Your Name
